question: I bought a starter kit for brewing beer. I followed the steps in the tutorial and got a very bitter beer. Why?

Hop Addition Timing: Hops are the main source of bitterness in beer. If you added all or most of the hops at the very beginning of the boil (instead of splitting them, as suggested—some at the beginning for bitterness, the rest near the end for aroma), this will extract more bitter compounds (alpha acids), increasing the overall bitterness. Proper timing—most for aroma in the last 15 minutes—can balance this.
Boil Intensity: Boiling your wort too vigorously can intensify hop utilization, leading to more bitterness. It’s best to maintain a steady “rolling boil,” not an aggressive one.
Hop Quantity: Accidentally adding more hops than recommended or adding them too early both result in higher bitterness. With starter kits, double-check measurements and timing.
Recipe Style: Some starter kits (often “IPA” or “Pilsner” styles) are designed to be more bitter. Check your kit’s description—some bitterness is intentional and style-appropriate.
Water Chemistry: High levels of carbonate or high pH can accentuate bitterness perception. Kits usually assume tap water is neutral, but if your water is very hard or alkaline, this might contribute.
Production Tips:
For your next batch, try splitting the hop additions: most at the beginning (for bitterness), a smaller portion in the final 10-15 minutes (for aroma).
Always measure hops carefully using a digital scale.
Moderate your boil to a gentle roll.
